title.narrative: OTP 5: ALL CHILDREN IN QUALITY LEARNING

description.narrative: By 2017, the government promotes full enrolment and retention of all children (3-15), especially most vulnerable, and applies new education standards for learning environments and outcomes., which contributes to Early Learning, Equity â€“ Focus On Girls' And Inclusive Education, Learning And Child-Friendly Schools, Learning Outcomes. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2017, the Government addresses disparities in access to quality education, health, protection and justice services for disadvantaged children and families.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2017, the government promotes full enrolment and retention of all children (3-15), especially most vulnerable, and applies neweducation standards for learning environments and outcomes.

description.narrative: Inclusive Education efforts brought further integration of children with disabilities and Roma children in mainstream schools and clear commitment was taken on the General Comment 4 to Article 24 of the CRPD. A per-capita financing formula for preschools is developed and will be piloted by the World Bank. | Status:Met | As-of Date:12/01/2018

title.narrative: Number of communities that have Roma segregated schools or classes
Percentage of educators trained on child centred methodology or inclusive education
Percentage of pupils competent in reading, mathematics and sciences (PISA report)

baseline.value: 43 % competent in reading, 39% in mathematics, 53% in sciences

target.value: 2017:10 percentage points increase in each of the three areas

actual.value: 2017:2015 PISA resultsReading 54,2% (11 p.p. increase)Maths 49,7% (10 p.p. increase)Science 57,8% (5 p.p. increase)
